title: Rafael Nadal, Daniil Medvedev Advance to U.S. Open Men’s Final
text:
Rafael Nadal needs one more win to put himself within one major title of the all-time record.

The Spaniard advanced to the U.S. Open men’s final by cruising past Matteo Berrettini, 7-6(6), 6-4, 6-1 on Friday night. On Sunday, he’ll face Russian Daniil Medvedev, who had a similarly easy time dispensing with Grigor Dimitrov of Bulgaria, 7-6(5), 6-4, 6-3. A victory would give Nadal his 19th career major title, one shy of Roger Federer’s mark of 20.

“Of course, I would love to be the one who achieves the most grand slams,” Nadal said. “But you can’t spend all day frustrated or thinking about what your neighbor has.”

The final will pit one of the perennial favorites at Arthur Ashe Stadium against its new favorite heel. Medvedev, a 23-year-old ranked fifth in the world, has embraced the role of antagonist over the past two weeks.

It will be a contrast in experience as much as in personas. Medvedev will appear in his first career Grand Slam final. For Nadal, it will be the 27th of his career, his fifth at a U.S. Open and his third of this year alone. Nadal won the French Open and finished runner-up at the Australian Open.

Berrettini, 23 years old and the 25th-ranked player in the world, gave Nadal a scare in the first set. After neither player broke serve, he went up 4-0 in the tiebreaker. But after Nadal rallied to cut the deficit to 6-5, Berrettini lost the next three points—and as a result, the set—on three consecutive unforced errors.

It was a stirring turn of events that turned a potential upset in the making into a predictable outcome. After the two played to a 3-3 tie in the second set, Nadal finally broke serve for the first time.

“After that, the match completely changed,” he said. “I started to play with more calm.” He won nine of the last 11 games.

Nadal has won the U.S. Open three times, most recently in 2017, when he beat Kevin Anderson. That final was a clear mismatch, with Anderson coming into the tournament as the No. 32 seed. Medvedev represents a far more legitimate challenge.

Daniil Medvedev is 20-2 on hardcourts this summer and has reached the finals in four consecutive tournaments. Photo: robert deutsch/Reuters

Dimitrov was coming off a win over Federer in the quarterfinals. But after taking the first set to a tiebreaker, Dimitrov gave Medvedev little cause for concern.

What Medvedev’s gangly swing lacks in aesthetic quality, it makes up for in effectiveness. At 6-foot-6, he covers much of the court with a wingspan that makes it hard for opponents to get the ball past him.

So it went for Dimitrov. It was Medvedev’s first straight-set victory since the first round of the tournament, and it continued what has been a summer of dominance.

Medvedev is 20-2 on hardcourts this summer and has reached the finals in four consecutive tournaments. He won the Western and Southern Open in Mason, Ohio, lost to Nadal in the final at the Rogers Cup in Montreal and finished second at the Citi Open in Washington.

On Sunday, he’ll become only the second Russian and the first since Marat Safin in 2000 to appear in the U.S. Open men’s final.

“When I was going to U.S.A., I didn’t know it was going to be that good,” Medvedev cracked during his on-court interview. “I have to say, I love the U.S.A.”

The mostly drama-free evening represented a change of pace for Medvedev. He overcame cramps in his second-round match, angered fans by holding up his middle finger in the third round and invited the crowd to boo him in the fourth round. He was jeered lustily during the quarterfinals.

But by the end of Friday’s match, the fans seemed to appreciate what Medvedev’s antics had largely overshadowed: his sheer talent. He received a warm ovation as he walked off the court. He tapped his racket as if clapping in response, with no apparent sarcasm. Afterward, he spoke of Nadal in reverential terms.

“He’s just a machine, a beast on the court,” Medvedev said. “To play him in your first Grand Slam final should be, I want to say, a funny thing. It’s not going to be a funny thing, but it’s going to be an amazing thing to live.”

Write to BRIAN COSTA at brian.costa@wsj.com
description: Rafael Nadal needs one more win to put himself within one major title of the all-time record. He advanced to the U.S. Open men’s final by cruising past Matteo Berrettini on Friday night
